text.value: Now match the statement on the right with the relevant interpretation on the left.

value.value: Presents Henry VIII as a religious hero.
Invites the reader to settle a quick question which, either way, will reflect well on the Tudor family.
Presents Henry VII as a war hero.
Makes an outrageous boast for both the painting and it's subjects.
The great debate, competition and great question is whether father or son is the victor. For both indeed were supreme.
If it pleases you to see the illustrious images of heroes, look on these: no picture ever bore greater.

The son, born indeed for greater things, removed the unworthy from their altars and replaces them by upright men: the arrogance of the popes has yielded to unerring virtue, and while Henry VIII holds the sceptre in his hands religion is restored and during his reign the doctrines of God have begun to be held in his honour.
The former often overcame his enemies and the conflagrations of his country, and finally brought peace to its citizens.
